articles.headline: In Groupon’s $6 Billion Wake, a Fleet of Start-Ups
articles.snippet: Since Groupon declined a Google buyout offer, hundreds of companies have launched, trying to emulate its business model by targeting narrow slices of the market.
articles.abstract: Since Groupon declined a Google buyout offer, hundreds of companies have launched, trying to emulate its business model by targeting narrow slices of the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is there no limit to the passion of American shoppers for online daily-deal discounts?

articles.headline: Heat Damages Colombia Coffee, Raising Prices
articles.snippet: Changes linked to global warming have contributed to a shortage of the beans used in specialty coffees.
articles.abstract: Changes linked to global warming have contributed to a shortage of the beans used in specialty coffees.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIMBÍO, Colombia  Like most of the small landowners in Colombia’s lush mountainous Cauca region, Luis Garzón, 80, and his family have thrived for decades by supplying shade-grown, rainforest-friendly Arabica coffee for top foreign brands like Nespresso and Green Mountain. A sign in the center of a nearby town proclaims, “The coffee of Cauca is No. 1!”

articles.headline: Resignation Comes at Sensitive Time for NPR
articles.snippet: After an embarrassing video came out, NPR, which is in a fight in Congress over its subsidy, lost its chief executive.
articles.abstract: After an embarrassing video came out, NPR, which is in a fight in Congress over its subsidy, lost its chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the midst of a brutal battle with Republican critics in Congress over federal subsidies, NPR has lost its chief executive after yet another politically charged embarrassment.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Jensen and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Wisconsin Senate Limits Bargaining by Public Workers
articles.snippet: The bitter standoff over Gov. Scott Walker’s bid to limit collective bargaining for public workers ended after the Republicans used a procedural maneuver to force the measure through.
articles.abstract: The bitter standoff over Gov. Scott Walker’s bid to limit collective bargaining for public workers ended after the Republicans used a procedural maneuver to force the measure through.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  The bitter political standoff in Wisconsin over Gov. Scott Walker’s bid to sharply curtail collective bargaining for public-sector workers ended abruptly Wednesday night as Republican colleagues in the State Senate successfully maneuvered to adopt a bill doing just that.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Approves Drug for Lupus, an Innovation After 50 Years
articles.snippet: Benlysta, the first new drug to treat lupus in more than half a century, is the first product approved for its developer, Human Genome Sciences.
articles.abstract: Benlysta, the first new drug to treat lupus in more than half a century, is the first product approved for its developer, Human Genome Sciences.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first new drug to treat lupus in more than half a century won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, offering a new option for people with lupus, an often-debilitating immune system disease.

articles.headline: Appeal of iPad 2 Is a Matter of Emotions
articles.snippet: The new iPad is thinner, lighter and faster. It makes more of a difference than you might think.
articles.abstract: The new iPad is thinner, lighter and faster. It makes more of a difference than you might think.
articles.lead_paragraph: “An utter disappointment and abysmal failure” (Orange County Web Design Blog). “Consumers seem genuinely baffled by why they might need it” (Businessweek). “Insanely great it is not” (MarketWatch). “My god, am I underwhelmed” (Gizmodo).

articles.headline: Revolts Raise Fear of Migration in Europe
articles.snippet: With the turmoil in Libya and elsewhere in the region, many Europeans worry they will face waves of illegal immigration.
articles.abstract: With the turmoil in Libya and elsewhere in the region, many Europeans worry they will face waves of illegal immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAMPEDUSA, Italy  Until a few weeks ago, the immigrant transfer center on this tiny Mediterranean island  a kind of Italian Ellis Island  was empty. An extensive European campaign against migration from Africa was considered so effective that the authorities basically shut it down.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Suzanne Daley

articles.headline: Hoard of Cash Lets Qaddafi Extend Fight Against Rebels
articles.snippet: The Libyan leader has control over “tens of billions” in cash stored in banks, allowing him to pay his troops, African mercenaries and political supporters, officials said.
articles.abstract: The Libyan leader has control over “tens of billions” in cash stored in banks, allowing him to pay his troops, African mercenaries and political supporters, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has “tens of billions” in cash secretly hidden away in Tripoli, allowing him to prolong his fight against rebel forces despite an international freeze on many of the Libyan government’s assets, according to American and other intelligence officials.
articles.byline: By James Risen and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Qaddafi Forces Bear Down on Strategic Town as Rebels Flee
articles.snippet: Rebels retreated from Ras Lanuf after an assault by forces loyal to the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, underlining a shift in momentum.
articles.abstract: Rebels retreated from Ras Lanuf after an assault by forces loyal to the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, underlining a shift in momentum.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAS LANUF, Libya  The momentum shifted decisively Thursday in an uprising that has shaken Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s four decades of rule, as rebels fled from this strategic refinery town under a sustained land, air and sea assault by government forces.

articles.headline: Anxiety About Oil, Recovery Send Shares Lower
articles.snippet: The Dow closed below 12,000, as oil market jitters and the conflict in Libya served as a reminder of the fragile nature of the global recovery.
articles.abstract: The Dow closed below 12,000, as oil market jitters and the conflict in Libya served as a reminder of the fragile nature of the global recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: Worries about oil supply and downbeat economic reports from three continents sent stocks worldwide sharply lower on Thursday, providing a reminder of the fragile nature of the global recovery.

articles.headline: In Wisconsin Battle on Unions, State Democrats See a Gift
articles.snippet: Governor Scott Walker of Wisconsin won his battle to cut bargaining rights but his victory also carries risks for the state’s Republicans.
articles.abstract: Governor Scott Walker of Wisconsin won his battle to cut bargaining rights but his victory also carries risks for the state’s Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis.  After nearly a month of angry demonstrations and procedural maneuvering in the State Capitol here, Gov. Scott Walker won his battle on Thursday to cut bargaining rights for most government workers in Wisconsin.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and A. G. Sulzberger
